Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF CNIC

US-Singapore Workshop: Collaborative Research: Understand the World by Analyzing Many Video Streams


Many thousands of network cameras provide near real-time view of the world. Valuable scientific information could be extracted by analyzing the large amounts of data. However, most of the data are never analyzed or archived. Analysis programs must be able to retrieve data from distributed sources, manage network accesses, schedule computation resources, allocate storage space, analyze the data, store the results, and present the results in formats that are easy to comprehend. Although the data are available, analyses today are limited due to the lack of a software framework to write and execute computer programs.


To harvest the knowledge from the data, the researchers from six universities are creating a system that can analyze the vast amount of visual data. The team will organize a workshop in December 2014 in Singapore. In this workshop, the team will share the information of the projects currently been conducted independently in the six universities. The researchers will present and demonstrate their projects, discuss and develop a plan for collaboration. The team includes Yung-Hsiang Lu (lead, Purdue University), Ketan Mayer-Patel (University of North Carolina), Cong Liu (University of Texas Dallas), Wei Tsang Ooi (National University of Singapore), Jason Gu (Singapore University of Technology and Design), Yonggang Wen (Nanyang Technological University).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop was held on December 16 and 17, 2014 in the School of Computer Science of the National University of Singapore (NUS). Six faculty members (3 from USA and 3 from Singapore) and 10 students presented in the workshop. Each faculty member or student gave a presentation. Each student also gave a poster presentation. The presentation topics include

  • The Purdue CAM2 (Continuous Analysis of Many CAMeras) system Network design for managing many video streams 
  • Real­time visual analytics 
  • Crowd­source geo­tagged video
  • Content and application adaptive video compression
  • Interactive television and cloud-based video analysis

The faculty are Roger Zimmermann and Wei Tsang Ooi (National University of Singapore), Yung­Hsiang Lu (Purdue University), Cong Liu (University of Texas), Ketan Mayer­Patel (University of North Carolina), and Yonggang Wen (Nanyang Technological University).

The students are Kyle McNulty, Everett Berry, Seth Bontrager, Ahmed Kaseb, and Youngsol Koh (Purdue), Yichao Jin, Weida Xu, Jianxiong Yin, and Xiao Liu (Nanyang Technological University), Ying Zhang (National University of Singapore).

The outcomes of this workshop include:

A research paper published in IEEE Cloud Computing September/October 2015 (featured article of the issue). This paper describes some important problems when creating a cloud­based system for analyzing many video streams. The title of the paer is "Analysis of Large­Scale Distributed Cameras Using Cloud", The authors are Wenyi Chen, Anup Mohan, Yung­Hsiang Lu, Thomas Hacker, Wei Tsang Ooi, and Edward J Delp,

A panel was organized by Yung­Hsiang Lu and Yonggang Wen for ACM Multimedia 2015
discussing "Opportunities and Challenges of Globally Networked Cameras". The panelists are Joanna Batstone, Touradj Ebrahimi, Hanqing Lu, and Yonggang Wen.

This proposal was declined. On October 12 and 13, 2015, a Purdue student Charles Hansen visited Nanyang Technological University and National Universitiy of Singapore, presenting the progress of the CAM2 project.
